text: {{Infobox writer | birth_name = James Grover Thurber | image = James Thurber NYWTS.jpg | birth_date = | birth_place = Columbus, Ohio, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = New York City, U.S. | occupation = Humorist | nationality = American | period = 1894–1961 | genre = short stories, cartoons, essays | subject = humor, language | notableworks = My Life and Hard Times, My World and Welcome to It }} James Grover Thurber (December 8, 1894 – November 2, 1961) was an American author, journalist, and cartoonist. Thurber was best known for his cartoons and short stories. He published his stories mainly in The New Yorker magazine. One of the most popular humorists of his time, Thurber celebrated the comic frustrations and eccentricities of ordinary people. Thurber died on November 2, 1961 from complications from pneumonia and a stroke, aged 66. His last words, aside from the repeated word "God," were "God bless...
